parts:
Help me repair this LaTeX

---

Let $q > 1$ be a power of $2$. Let

$$f : \mathbb{F}*{q^2} \to \mathbb{F}*{q^2}$$

be an affine map over $\mathbb{F}_2$. Show that the equation

$$f(x) = x^{q+1}$$

has at most $2q - 1$ solutions.

Here, $\mathbb{F}*{q^2}$ denotes the Galois Field (or finite field) of order $q^2$.

Here’s a cleaned-up LaTeX version (your main issue is `\mathbb{F}*{q^2}` — `*` isn’t LaTeX syntax here; you want a subscript). I also tightened the wording slightly.

```latex
Let $q>1$ be a power of $2$. Let
\[
f:\mathbb{F}_{q^2}\to \mathbb{F}_{q^2}
\]
be an affine map over $\mathbb{F}_2$. Show that the equation
\[
f(x)=x^{q+1}
\]
has at most $2q-1$ solutions in $\mathbb{F}_{q^2}$.

Here, $\mathbb{F}_{q^2}$ denotes the finite field of order $q^2$.
```

Optional (more explicit about “affine over \(\mathbb F_2\)”):

```latex
Let $q>1$ be a power of $2$. Let
\[
f:\mathbb{F}_{q^2}\to \mathbb{F}_{q^2}
\]
be an $\mathbb{F}_2$-affine map (i.e.\ $f(x)=L(x)+b$ with $L$ $\mathbb{F}_2$-linear and $b\in\mathbb{F}_{q^2}$). Show that
\[
f(x)=x^{q+1}
\]
has at most $2q-1$ solutions in $\mathbb{F}_{q^2}$.
```

If you want, paste your full source (preamble etc.) and I’ll match your style (equation environments, theorem style, notation like \(\mathrm{GF}(q^2)\), etc.).
